div.p:
I congratulate you with all
my heart upon your son
Francis's success, and upon
the prizes he has won, and
I think this must be more
satisfactory to you and of
better promise for his future
life than if all had been more
easily and more early attained

He now knows fully his
own powers and the differ
ence difference between what they can
and will do for him with
and without exention and
application & self control
- And he is of an age when
this must make serious im-
pression impression and in circumstances
which must surely render
that impression lasting -
going into has a new world
where he has a character as
well as fortune to make for
himself and where away
far from his fond father &
all his family he is will reflect
either honor or dishonor upon
them and be the pride of
that fathers heart or perhaps
break that affectionate heart

Please to read this to him
with my anxious wishes
for his health and happiness
and for his becoming an
honor to his family and
worthy in all situations of
the education he has received
and the name he bears -

I am very much
obliged to you my dear
Francis for writing to me
with your own hand this
account of your son which
truly gives me very great plea
-sure pleasure - both from the thing
itself and from your kindness
and certainly of my sympathy

Thank you for Mr Whewells
book which I particularly
wished to see before I answer
Mr Jones's letter - I shall write
to Mr Jones now; I waited till
the Examination was over
when I thought I could do
so with more propriety than
while the decision was pending
- now it will be delightful
to me - I shall may say (I hope?
that you will be glad to become
acquainted with Mr Jones when
ever he comes to Town - And
that you never declined the
interview formerly proposed -
- I will take care not to throw
any blame on Mr. Whewell's
forgetfulness or mistake.

I have read from the page
143 "Remarks on Mathematical reason
-ing & on the Logic of induction"
- But till I have read it again &
again cannot tell you how much
pleasure it can give me at
the first reading I like it much
- But I think the inquiry must
be pursued deeper still - This
proves sufficiently that mathematical
reasoning and demonstration cannot
be founded on definitions - only - with-
out withou axioms - but axioms resolve themselves
or must be resolved into some action
of the mind - a conception - an idea - or
What Whewell (p 156) calls an intellection
- See also p 166 - idea of statistical force - pressure
idea of body or matter

All this seems to me to come round again
to intuitive ideas - or intuition - or what
Stewart & Reid call original instincts - laws
of belief

I do not agree with Mr. W's objection 157
by the term laws of belief. I do not understand
why he conceives that laws compel results
- I considered laws as synonymous to rules -
formed from observation of what constantly occurs
in certain circumstances - or between in
certain relations of things - persons
or thoughts to each other

It seems to me that writers
go round & round again and
come to the same points & stops
in ???physics - & some coin
new terms instead of saying
- we know no more -

Locke who maintains that we
have no innate ideas -

Stewart who maintains that we
have what he calls mental instincts
including the instinct of credulity
and the instinct of belief

Mr. Whewell who says that "an axiom
"does not account for an intellection"
Which he explains elsewhere to
mean an act of the mind - an idea
- a clear conception -

All - all - come to the acknowledg-
ment that there is something more
in mind than words can express
or something more than we know
of The act of induction what do we know?
div.closer:
I know that I am my dear
Francis wasting your time
But I am affectionately yours
Maria Edgeworth
